STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 07, 2022
Scott Parrott
Gogebic Iron Ontonagon DHHS
301 E. Lead Street
Bessemer, MI 49911
RE: License #: CP270201149
Gogebic Iron Ontonagon DHHS
301 E. Lead Street
Bessemer, MI 49911
Dear Mr. Parrott:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on June 10,
2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP270201149
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Gogebic Iron Ontonagon DHHS
Facility Address: 301 E. Lead Street
Bessemer, MI 49911
Facility Telephone #: (906) 663-6200
Original Issuance Date: 08/01/1990
Service Types: License foster homes. Placement of children
in foster care. Supervise independent living
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
One of 1 borrowed home files did not contain documentation that the foster parent
was willing to accept the foster child.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation
is acceptable.
One of 1 borrowed home files did not contain documentation of written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the initial evaluation is acceptable.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation
is acceptable.
4

One of 1 borrowed home files did not contain documentation of written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the renewal evaluation is acceptable.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age and
older, including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed
not more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of 4 foster care files reviewed lacked documentation of a dental exam within 90
days after placement.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans: Parent Agency Treatment Plans.
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable.
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor, when
siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who are a
member of a participating household. • Youth ages 14 and
older. • Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
courtordered caregivers.
5

Three of four foster care files reviewed lacked PATP signatures or the signatures
were late, beyond 30 days of the completion of the treatment plan. One file
contained a initial PATP completed on January 29, 2022 and the plan was signed on
March 7, 2022. The same file contained a PATP dated April 29, 2022, that lacked
signatures. A second file contained an PATP dated July 14, 2021, that was signed
by the parent on August 26, 2021. The plan also lacked foster parent signatures. A
third file contained a PATP dated January 7, 2022, and signatures were dated
February 17, 2022. The signature of the foster parent was late.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following: Updated Case Plan (USP) - within
30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Two of four foster care files reviewed contained partially completed DHHS-1105
documentation or were missing FTM’s for a service plan period. One DHHS -1105
dated March 17, 2022, was incomplete and did not document signatures. The same
file contained a DHHS -1105 dated September 28, 2021, that was incomplete and
did not document signatures. A second file did not contain documentation of an FTM
occurring for a service plan period ending April 7, 2022. The file also did not contain
a FTM occurring for a service plan ending January 7, 2022.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passports
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to: • Participating
legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement. At reunification.
Subsequent medical passports are not required after
reunification. • The child’s foster care provider: At or prior
to each placement. Quarterly.
6

One of four foster care files reviewed did not contain an updated medical passport
for the time period from July 16, 2021, to February 24, 2022.
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary, must be completed at the time of program
closure; see FOM 722-08E, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice
Action Summary.
The caseworker must complete the DHHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MISACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change, (3 days).
One of two closed foster care files reviewed contained a DHHS-69 Action Summary
that was completed three months after the case was closed. The case was closed
on October 21, 2021, and the action summary was not completed until January 24,
2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas.
 A newly hired agency foster care worker did not complete an observation of the
child’s sleeping arrangements during a May 19, 2022 foster home visit. The
agency Program Supervisor detected the incomplete safety assessment at or
about the time of the DCWL audit and put corrective action into place with the
worker. Recommended increased supervision of face to face in home contacts
with new workers.
 Of the social work face to face contacts reviewed, one was entered beyond the
five working days requirement. The Chief Administrators Annual Assessment
indicated that the agency was aware of the policy violation and had implemented
a corrective action plan which had corrected the policy violation except for the
one contact noted above. It was recommended that workers be given weekly
structured time for entering contacts.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
7

this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A corrective action plan, approved May 17, 2021, was submitted in response to the
Renewal Inspection completed on May 4, 2021. There were no repeat violations
established during the current Interim Inspection. The agency continues to
successfully address and correct rule and policy violations established during the
previous annual inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA)
The CAA was reviewed and it was thorough in addressing violations and CAP
successes during the licensing period. The assessment identified areas of deficiency
and corrective action taken.
Interviews:
Two interviews were conducted with staff. One interview was with a foster care
worker and the second interview was conducted with a foster care worker who is
also performing licensing functions while the licensing worker is on medical leave.
Each staff indicated that they receive competent and supportive supervision from
their supervisor as well as other administrative staff. They also reported that they
feel they are part of a team that is supportive. Two Administrative staff were
interviewed and spoke of the challenges they meet with staff turnover, the effects of
the pandemic, and frequent system and policy changes. Administrative staff were
positive regarding the staff and the team at the agency.
Field Analyst Findings:
The Field Analyst identified one safety concern while visiting agency homes. The
Field Analyst generated a safety alert on March 8, 2022, and notified the agency on
that date. The identified safety concern was an inoperable smoke alarm. The agency
Licensing Worker visited the home on March 8, 2022 and installed a new smoke
alarm. The safety alert concern was resolved. The Analyst indicated during the
entrance conference that homes visited reported feeling supported by the agency
and satisfied with services.
8

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
June 29, 2022
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 6, 2022
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Area Manager
9
